summary: Howard J. Osborn was the Director of Security for the CIA. Documents show his involvement in key personnel assignments within the Office of Security, including reassignments of Arthur C. Sheridan, James W. McCord, Jr., and James P. O'Connell, Jr. He was also involved in the covert security approval process for individuals like Robert West Pugh, who was associated with Project HBILKA/JBGREED. Osborn testified about CIA mail opening projects such as SR POINTER and West Pointer, acknowledging that some operations involved opening mail without explicit authorization and that higher-ups like Mr. Helms were aware of the New York mail openings. His testimony also covered activities of the CIA's Office of Security, including electronic and physical surveillance, Watergate contacts, covert informers, mail intercepts, and cooperation with local police.
significance: Howard J. Osborn's significance in the JFK context stems from his role as Director of Security for the CIA and his involvement in various sensitive operations, including mail intercepts and surveillance activities. While the documents do not directly link him to the JFK assassination, his position and the activities under his purview are of interest to investigations examining potential CIA connections or knowledge related to the assassination. The JFK Assassination System Identification Form mentions CIA files related to James Earl Ray and Arthur J. Hanes.
